abstracts.cdata!:
Project performance ratings are as
            follows: Outcome is satisfactory, sustainability is likely,
            institutional development impact is substantial, and the
            performances of both the Bank and the Borrower are
            satisfactory. These are some of the lessons learned: 1)
            Planning the project more deliberately as a standard
            investment loan would have enabled better preparation of
            procurement and institutional arrangements before appraisal.
            2) Procurement planning must be done from the beginning. In
            addition, it would have been preferable to have drawings,
            specifications and terms of reference for the first year of
            implementation prepared before appraisal. Modum operandi
            between the Project Coordination Unit and the implementing
            agencies should be written in the operational manual. 3)
            Gabion works for slope stabilization and riverbank
            protection proved to be an effective, easy and
            labor-intensive way to implement mitigation works. 4) It
            would have been preferable to process the various
            loan/credit for the different OECS countries as separate
            projects part of a broader program, but not integrated into
            one horizontal APL. In the Bank system, APL phases each
            correspond to one project (i.e. with one Project
            Identification Number (P0 number)) which does not allow for
            a segregation of reporting and accounting on individual
            sub-projects. The task team had important problem at the
            beginning of the program to obtain differentiated P0 number
            for each country. 5) Reconstruction components often require
            careful assessment and long term effort that generally
            extends beyond the normal three year implementation period
            for Bank-assisted emergency operations. Therefore, priority
            in this type of projects should be given to prevention,
            immediate measures to reactivate economic activity and
            careful assessment of longer-term reconstruction priorities
            and designs. 6) Ad hoc implementation arrangements through
            Project Coordination Units need to be carefully considered.
            In projects lacking a critical mass of work it is difficult
            for governments to allocate enough of their scarce qualified
            manpower to these units. 7) Terms of Reference for
            consulting engineers need to specify government budget
            constraints to avoid over-designed infrastructure that will
            be unaffordable to implement. The Bank needs to consider
            requiring performance guarantees of consultants and applying
            penalties for late submissions.
